Award.AwardTitle: The Stacks Project in Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to continue the work of the principal investigator on the Stacks project, a collaborative online open source textbook and reference work on algebraic geometry. The goal is to develop and document the theory of algebraic geometry, starting from basic algebra and set theory and leading up to the theory of algebraic stacks. The Stacks project gives pointers to the literature and formulates natural questions, in this way closing the gap between graduate education and current research. The project website (http://stacks.math.columbia.edu/) provides several ways of interacting with the material, as well as a system to leave comments and questions on the material. This project also involves a workshop where participants work on both the mathematics and further developing the website of the Stacks project.

Algebraic stacks are widely used, especially for thinking about moduli spaces, and are one of the most important tools in algebraic geometry today. On the one hand, the Stacks project text will clarify and give a clear exposition of "folklore" and older results in the literature, and on the other hand, recent methods and discoveries will be used in the exposition of foundational results. During the course of such activities, mathematical questions arise naturally; the principal investigator intends to study these and, in collaboration with others, answer them and carefully document the answers. The principal investigator will also continue to research other problems in arithmetic algebraic geometry, both independently and jointly with postdoctoral associates and graduate students. This award is co-funded by the Algebra and Number Theory program and the Infrastructure program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is the project outcomes report on the NSF grant "The Stacks Project in Algebraic Geometry". The Principal Investigator (PI) of this award, Professor Johan de Jong, collaborated with graduate students, post-docs, faculty as well as other researchers on algebraic geometry. Most of the effort went into studying and documenting the material leading up to and including the theory of algebraic stacks. As an important part of this work, the PI maintained and improved the Stacks project.

The Stacks project is an online resource for researchers and students in algebraic geometry. It is a massively collaborative ongoing project. It is an open source textbook as well as a reference work on algebraic geometry. Visitors to the online Stacks project can leave comments and suggestions to improve the exposition as well as correct errors and point out typos. Although the Stacks project started specifically aimed at foundations for algebraic stacks, it has over time come to include more and more parts of the basic theory developed in algebraic geometry.

We find links to the Stacks project on question-and-answer sites and on many websites of algebraic geometers. Many preprints on the ArXiv server in algebraic geometry use the Stacks project as a basic reference for results on commutative algebra, sheaf theory, cohomology, algebraic geometry, and of course algebraic stacks. As these preprints are published also more and more papers in the published literature contain references to the Stacks project. One of the major outcomes of this NSF award is the succes of the Stacks project as a resource for people in the field of algebraic geometry.
